I have migrated the best of the pictures from my trip to the US west coast to a separate folder on my homepage. I am sorry, this is a rush-y job and so not terribly user friendly. For those who are not very computer-savvy, just click here or on the previous link (same thing) and you will get a page with a bunch of file names, which are somewhat descriptive of what the picture is. Click on any name to see the picture and then use the back button on your browser to return to the list. And for anyone for whom even that is too much trouble, here are some thumbnails of the best pics for immediate viewing:

I have this condition called benign positional vertigo.  It recurs quite infrequently (which is good!) but when it's been awhile since I have had an attack of it, I almost forget I have it, or think hopefully that it may have gone away for good.  But I had it really bad this morning, and had to stay home from work.  It's miserable and debilitating.
http://deborama.livejournal.com/11119.html

I have been meaning to do a little personal blogging in there amongst the commentary and "reportage" but every time I come to my computer meaning to do it, I end up playing solitaire or some other variety of time-wasting. I think I am just too mentally depleted by my job. Or something. I have a lot of interesting little stories saved up - DH and I had a night on the tiles about a month ago and I really meant to post something about that. And various other things. I had a big payout on an investment of sorts and have a few thou to reinvest or spend. That's not something I am used to. So I did something quite uncharacteristic and bought myself a lovely toy. DH and I went out yesterday to look at printers, clothing, sofas and coffee makers. We have two hideous, ancient, falling-apart suites, one that he had before I came here - many years before - and another almost as old that we got from his parents. The coffee pot was because our cheap filter-drip machine died a few weeks back. It already had an annoying crack in the plastic housing, and then someone dropped the carafe on the floor and shattered it. So we have been discussing getting a real, serious espresso machine. The printer was something DH thought we could use - a colour laser printer. And clothes - well, why not? OK, I am not even going to try to make this story short; I'm just going to ramble. We went to our nearest suburban-sprawl retail multiplex (Fosse Park). We started with the furniture stores. We found a small sofa we liked and decided to go home with the measurements, look around the lounge, mentally rearranging it, and make the decision from home. That took a while. Then we went to look for printers at a PC World. We didn't plan to buy anything there, just look at printers. While DH was looking at printers, I wandered over to the digital camera counter. I have been thinking of taking an adult ed course in digital photography. So the guy at the counter was showing me these cameras and he put one in my hand that I just totally fell in love with. The thought inserted itself as I looked at it and felt it in my hand - "object of desire". I am not usually subject to longings for material things, except a few specific things, like gloves, and bookplates, and really elegant pens. This was sort of like that, a fetishy feeling, but it was all about the evident quality of the thing. Reader, I bought it. And I still love it the next day. This is the one. The review really doesn't do it justice. That little thing on the front that says Cybershot on it is slid upwards to cover the lens. This turns the camera off, and sliding it back down turns it on. The viewscreen is almost the whole back of the unit, except for a tiny little control panel. It has a docking station for uploading your pictures or viewing your pictures or recharging the battery. Here's a picture of our back garden, which I have named "Suburban Sky" (the picture, not our back garden), that I took with it. So, we also bought an espresso maker and a coffee maker. The espresso maker is this one. Yeah, not usually thought of as an upscale brand, but this is a serious piece of kitchen kit and surprisingly high quality. Been trying it out - DH has been trying it out all day! He's going to be a right mess about 2 am tomorrow. We couldn't find any clothes I liked. And we ordered two two-seater sofas, a chair and a footstool when we got back home. I'm all shopped out for the moment.
http://deborama.livejournal.com/10846.html

I got a big charge out of this article in the Guardian: The big fat con story, an excerpt from Paul Campos's book, The Obesity Myth. Here's a good quote: 'The single most noxious line of argument in the literature about obesity is that black and Hispanic girls and women need to be "sensitised" to the "fact" that they have inappropriately positive feelings about their bodies. Readers may suspectthis is a bad joke: I wish it were. One University of Arizona study found that, while only 10% of the white teenage girls surveyed were happy with their bodies, 70% of the black teenage girls were happy with theirs (the black girls weighed more, on average, than the white girls).' And another: 'In 1853, an upper-class Englishman could be quite unselfconscious about the fact that the mere sight of the urban proletariat disgusted him. In 2003, any upper-class white American liberal would be horrified to imagine that the sight of, say, a lower-class Mexican-American woman going into a Wal-Mart might somehow elicit feelings of disgust in his otherwise properly sensitised soul. But the sight of a fat woman - make that an "obese" - better yet a "morbidly [sic] obese" woman going into Wal-Mart... ah, that is something else again.'

This morning I saw a display of mass idiocy that was so stupid it was amusing. Nottingham has this lovely shiny new tram system. If you are unfamiliar with trams, they run on tracks embedded in the road surface, and with a few exceptions, they run alongside of traffic, and they cross traffic at the level, observing traffic lights just like buses and cars. There is a crossing near my office of the tramline with a heavily-used one-way street. As the tram came to the intersection, its way was blocked by a large delivery van parked in front of a pub, just inches from the track. Therefore, no clearance at all. The driver stopped and got out to ask the van driver to move away. As he got out of the tram, the traffic light changed, so that he was blocking four lanes of traffic. The trams are long and bendy, with four carriages, so it was the rear carriage blocking the road, and the driver and the van was just out of sight up the tramline. One old geezer got really incensed at the tram so he started blowing his horn, vigorously, and - here's the stupid part - gesticulating madly at the passengers in the back of the tram and shouting "Move" at them. And now here's the really stupid part - all the other drivers thought "What a great idea!" so they're all tooting and gesturing and shouting at the bemused passengers sitting innocently in the rear carriage of the tram. And me standing on the corner, almost up in this old geezer's face, and laughing so hard I couldn't go anywhere till I got over my fit of hysterics. Thanks, I needed that.
http://deborama.livejournal.com/10109.html

I have a bit of a thing about the moon. When the weather is fine, I like to meditate on the moon. (Well, not on the moon, but you know what I mean.) The past couple of nights there has been a lovely moon-venus conjunction. In our part of the world, it was exceedingly beautiful Monday night. I saw it as I got off the train, on the way to my yoga class and just after it (about 9 pm.) The moon was a waxing crescent, and slightly pale orange, and Venus was about three moon diameters away, above and to the right, and looked very blue and twinkly. It reminded me of these lyrics from Terrapin Station: "The spiral light of Venus, rising first and shining best "From the northwest corner of a brand-new crescent moon "Crickets and cicadas sing a rare and different tune" Except no crickets and cicadas; too cold.

Sorry I have been so absent from LiveJournal recently. I have started a new blog - that makes a total of 4 blogs, 2 links pages and LJ that I am trying (not too successfully to maintain.) My new blog may of interest to fellow logophiles - it is called Wordkeeper. It has a word of the day (which tends to get a day or so behind) and miscellaneous rants about grammar and diction, word-related humour, and a little of my own poetry and prose (so far just one short poem from a few years ago, but more to come.) So drop by if you're interested in that sort of thing.

A blogfriend of mine who goes by the sobriquet of Yorkshire Soul has created a booklist meme in response to a filmlist meme that he received and passed on. Here's his book list with my results; if you like it, change the bolds and italics to match your results. I have made a couple of editorial changes for the benefit of Americans; not all will know Sartre's "No Exit" by its French title, and we don't know who Elwyn Brooks is, but we all know E. B. White wrote Charlotte's Web. Book Meme. The rules are as per the film meme, bold for works you have read, italics for works you would like to. 1) Lord Of The Rings - J R R Tolkien 2) To Kill A Mockingbird - Harper Lee 3) Of Mice and Men - John Steinbeck 4) Animal Farm - George Orwell 5) War And Peace - Leo Tolstoy 6) Riders - Jilly Cooper 7) The Stand - Stephen King 8) The Sicilian - Mario Puzo 9) Pride and Prejudice - Jane Austen 10) Wuthering Heights - Emily Bronte 11) Great Expectations - Charles Dickens 12) The Saga Of The Exiles - Julian May 13) Sandman:The Dolls House - Neil Gaiman 14) Vurt - Jeff Noon 15) A House For Mr Biswas - V S Naipul 16) Endymion - Dan Simmons 17) Space - Stephen Baxter 18) Hi-Fidelity - Nick Hornby 19) The Dark Is Rising - Susan Cooper 20) Valley Of The Dolls - Jaqueline Susann 21) The Allan Clark Diaries - Allan Clark 22) Charlotte's Web - Elwyn Brooks [E. B. White] 23) The Scar - China Mieville 24) The Iliad - Homer 25) Peter Pan - J M Barrie 26) Mansfield Park - Jane Austen 27) Carry On Jeeves - P G Wodehouse 28) Porterhouse Blue - Tom Sharpe 29) Watership Down - Richard Adams 30) Tarka The Otter - Henry Williamson 31) Epitres - Voltaire 32) The Uplift War - David Brin 33) The Adventures Of Huckleberry Finn - Mark Twain 34) Adolf Hitler, My Part In His Downfall - Spike Milligan 35) Jennifer Government - Max Barry 36) Catch 22 - Joseph Heller 37) Watchmen - Alan Moore 38) Clan Of The Cave Bear - Jean M Auel 39) The Merchant Of Venice - Shakespeare 40) Tess Of The D'Urbervilles - Thomas Hardy 41) Consider Phlebus - Iain Banks 42) Parliaments - Thomas Carlyle 43) Tales Too Ticklish To Tell - Berke Breathed 44) The Day Of The Triffids - John Wyndham 45) Green Eggs And Ham - Dr Suess 46) A Traitor To Memory - Elizabeth George 47) I'll Be Seeing You - Mary Higgins Clark 48) The Stone Raft - Jose Saramago 49) Lord Of The Flies - William Golding 50) The God Of Small Things - Arundhati Roy 51) Alias Grace - Margeret Atwood 52) Fantastic Mr Fox - Roald Dahl 53) The Hunt For Red October - Tom Clancy 54) Count Zero - William Gibson 55) Zen And The Art Of Motorcycle Maintanence - Robert M Pirsig 56) Wilt - Tom Sharpe 57) The Silmarillion - J R R Tolkien 58) Time Enough For Love - Robert Heinlein 59) The Love Knot - Charlotte Bingham 60) Female Parts - Dario Fo 61) Beowulf - Seamus Heaney 62) Jurassic Park - Michael Crichton 63) The Forge Of God - Greg Bear 64) Jack Holborn - Leon Garfield 65) Bruno's Dream - Iris Murdoch 66) Harry Potter And The Chamber Of Secrets - J K Rowling 67) Praxis - Fay Weldon 68) The Monkey King - Timothy Mo 69) Stupid White Men - Michael Moore 70) 1984 - George Orwell 71) The Chronicles Of Thomas Covenant - Stephen Donaldson 72) From Hell - Alan Moore 73) 101 Dalmations 74) The Time Machine - H G Wells 75) Runaway - Lucy Irvine 76) Huis Clos [No Exit]- Jean Paul Satre 77) Love & Rockets - Jamie Hernandez 78) The Death Of Grass - John Christopher 79) Naked Lunch - William Burroughs 80) Fevre Dream - George R R Martin 81) Books Of Blood - Clive Barker 82) Antigone - Sophocles 83) Wealth Of Nations - Adam Smith 84) The Colour Of Magic - Terry Pratchett 85) Cry Wolf - Wilbur Smith 86) Barman Year One - Frank Miller 87) The Tale Of Peter Rabbit - Beatrix Potter 88) Point Of Origin - Patricia Cornwell 89) Jackdaws - Ken Follet 90) Idoru - William Gibson 91) The Code Of The Woosters - P G Wodehouse 92) Shardik - Richard Adams 93) Helliconia - Brian Aldiss 94) Macbeth - Shakespeare 95) Shattered - Dick Francis 96) Disgrace - J M Coetzee 97) Ink Paintings - Gao Xingjian 98) The Wasp Factory - Iain Banks 99) The Simple Art Of Murder - Raymond Chandler 100) Aenied - Virgil YS: There we go, fly little meme, fly.

I have not been posting daily on LJ for a couple of weeks now. The main blog got scant attention too, then since about the 3rd I have posted on it at least once a day then today I did a flurry and almost cleared my backlog of things I gotta say. So, if you're interested in that, look there. Here is the picture I went to Gulfport (many thousands of miles) to get: I'm the one in black blending in with the tree. The tall smiley new Mum is Aimee, my daughter and the cute little thing hanging off of her is Savannah, her daughter. And the one who looks like Scarlett O'Hara at 70 is my mother, who actually IS Scarlett O'Hara at 70.

Back to the UUUK that is.  I had an interesting and fun visit - no political arguments and surprisingly little contention of any kind.  Both adult children are doing pretty well (not that they couldn't both use some money if you're offering!)  And my parents are still going strong despite such calamities as having a broken neck and two rounds of surgery or being bitten by a dog while out walking.  I went shopping with my two younger sisters at an outlet mall in Gulfport, something we realised we had never done together (that's go shopping full stop, not just at this particular place.)
I am very out of touch with things.  They do have newspapers of a sort in Gulfport and the family is on the internet through AOL (which is a bugger to use when you're not used to it.)  But I only caught the high points.  My dad is a fan of Faux News and my Mum doesn't watch news unless something that is important to her has happened.  'Nuff said.  (But I love 'em anyway and I am not just saying that in case they read my blog, either.)
So maybe a real post with content and links and all that will come out tomorrow.  I need to readjust my sleep cycle now.
http://deborama.livejournal.com/7749.html

This is just a note to let folks know I am still around.  But around Gulfport Mississippi at the moment.  
My Mum got a new computer from my youngest brother for Christmas so this is what I am blogging on.  I am going to crash (me not the computer) pretty soon.  I got back to my Aged Ps' house from the party, which is why we are all here - it was my middle sister Cindy's 25th wedding anniversary.  There were at least 50 people there.  There were a lot of nostalgic tears.  And no political arguments; in fact no arguments of any kind.  Amazing.   
I am spending some good time with my grand-daughter.  There were two little babies, almost exactly the same age, at this party.  Shep, Cindy's husband, is 19 years older than she is, and his grand-daughter from a previous marriage had a baby girl the day after Savannah was born.  So my younger sister has a step-great-granddaughter one day younger than my only grand-daughter.  Kind of like that old "I'm My Own Grandpa" song.  But what's really cute is this baby is named Aspen.  So we have two babies at a family get-together not really related to each other, and both named after popular American holiday destinations.  
I got a cool new picture of my son Carey, which will be up on the Personal Page after I get home.  
We had a lot of good food, provided by my other sister Denise and my youngest brother Scott, who is attending chef school (his second career, after being a radio programme manager for many years.)
http://deborama.livejournal.com/7609.html

(Cross posted at Deborama's Kitchen). We actually had our main meal yesterday. I wanted to take it easy today because tomorrow I go on the long grueling journey to a family celebration. This involves a few hours on the road to Gatwick, a few hours at Gatwick, about 9 hours flying, a few hours in Detroit and then flying to Memphis, a couple of hours in Memphis then a (hopefully) quick hop to Gulfport, where it will be at least 11 pm the same day but will feel like 5 am the next day to me. Ugh. So, what we had (and still have). A very large, fat free-range-reared goose, simply roasted. Damson cheese, which I made back in early September. (I used Mrs. Beeton's recipe but this is pretty close.) Mashed cauliflower and celeriac with cream, and also, parboiled cauliflower and celeriac roasted in goose fat. Stir-fried thinly sliced brussels sprouts with shallots, chili and mushrooms. Wild rice with onion and celery. Chilled Cava Brut to drink.

We are having a goose this year and we are having our Christmas lunch today, and snacking on the leftovers tomorrow. And there will be a lot of leftovers; it says a 10-lb. goose will feed 8 and there are only the two of us and we ordered a 10-lb. goose but the darn thing would not quit eating and turned out to be a 16-lb. goose. Fortunately, it was mostly fat, which we have trimmed off a bit (there is a large mixing bowl full of un-rendered fat) and at least as much if not more will come off as it roasts. Goose fat keeps about 6 months in the fridge and is good for lots of uses, including feeding to the birds and frying things in (not me, though, I find the idea slightly repellent, but hubby does not have that problem, oh, no.) Also, he is planning to take some leftovers down to Kingsclere when he visits his aged Ps after dropping me at Gatwick for my trip to Mississippi. All of which is a very long introduction to say that for the first time in six years we are not having Christmas Salmon, a recipe of my own devising and quite outrageously good, for Christmas. But I put the recipe out there to make its way in the world.

I am the sonnet, never quickly thrilled;
Not prone to overstated gushing praise
Nor yet to seething rants and anger, filled
With overstretched opinions to rephrase;
But on the other hand, not fond of fools,
And thus, not fond of people, on the whole;
And holding to the sound and useful rules,
Not those that seek unjustified control.
I'm balanced, measured, sensible (at least,
I think I am, and usually I'm right);
And when more ostentatious types have ceased,
I'm still around, and doing, still, alright.
In short, I'm calm and rational and stable -
Or, well, I am, as much as I am able.
What Poetry Form Are You?
http://deborama.livejournal.com/6164.html

I found out I am finally going to get some work, and best of all I am finally going to be a "release manager" (glorified team leader really). It is mostly good news. Never mind that the part of the release I am meant to manage seems very ill-defined and to overlap almost totally with the part another novice release manager is covering. Never mind that the project as a whole is pretty hopeless, with unrealistic deadlines and clients who don't and can't and won't understand the product. Never mind! I will make it work! I always do! I ate a piece of chocolate today. Just one mouthful-sized piece of dark choc. Belgian truffle. Y'know, it wasn't all that good. Apart from that I had: Breakfast - 2 eggs f.i.b. & 2 veg. saus. (get tired of reading that? just think how tired I get of eating it) Mid-morning - cafe latte; 5 oz. espresso-choc Lunch - turley ham and swiss roll-ups; cottage cheese, very tiny green salad Dinner - salmon, leek, fennel and garlic in a cream-cheese sauce And I still haven't called my mother! My weblog got an exceptional spate of hits yesterday - about 70 I think. And the comments, which have been not working for most people most of the time, suddenly worked for a while and got hit a lot so I had about a dozen comments to read. And then I had what turned into a long post (for me); something I had to get off my chest, as it were. If you are interested in global politics with a slightly skewed, very anarcho-libertarian American ex-hippie ex-pat viewpoint, you may like my blog. Or not. :)
http://deborama.livejournal.com/6072.html

I only had 4 hours sleep last night.  I couldn't fall asleep till 12:30 for various reasons (the West Wing, whisky mac, my hurting knee) and then the senile girl dog started barking at 4:30 and grumpy hubby who WAS NOT hit by a car 5 days ago and DOES NOT have to get up and go to work put the pillow over his head and refused to get up.  So I did and I have felt like hell ever since.  So gotta get to sleep.

Food today:
Breakfast - 2 eggs fried in butter, 2 veg sausages, black tea
Lunch - my chicken salad (see link in earlier post), green salad
Snacks at work - 2 espresso-chocs (5 oz.) and 1 oz. peanuts
Dinner - 2 veg burger patties and a 3-egg omelette with cheese and broccoli, black decaf tea

I should call my mother, but I'll never get to bed in time if I do.  Sorry Mom.  Maybe tomorrow.
http://deborama.livejournal.com/5782.html

I had exactly what I said I would have for dinner, no more, no less. And the whisky-mac. I just finished watching the penultimate episode of whatever season of the West Wing they are showing here now - 4 I think. It was too powerful for my feeble middle-aged brain. I ought to go to bed but I am on a huge West Wing high and I am going to Television Without Pity to read about it. I am so bad. (It's the one where Zoe disappears at the end of it.) (Zoe annoys me, although not as much as that girl Josh dates, but I love Charlie, so I love Zoe for his sake.) (I know I'm very sad; you don't have to point it out.)
http://deborama.livejournal.com/5434.html

I stayed home again. I saw the osteopath on Saturday and I went to yoga last night and I am getting better, really, but I still have a lot of back pain, and it's a long, cramped ride to and from work, and a lot of standing around on hard train platforms in the cold, and I don't have much (anything?) to do at work, so I decided I could really use another day of rest. As is usually the case when I stay home and hubby is out, I got tons of cleaning and tidying done, things that always bother the hell out of me but I can never seem to do when he is here. I also went shopping at George, the "dry goods" section of Asda (read: British Walmart) and I bought a few gifties for my grand-daughter. It looks like both adult children of me have got their tickets to Mississippi, so we are all going to be there at roughly the same time. The oldest adult child has her own baby, the aforementioned grand-daughter, who will be almost 4 months old. It will be the first time the rest of the family have seen her. I hope it will be a good visit. There are a lot of emotional pits we could fall into, but maybe we will all behave ourselves. I know I will try, and the worst offenders (always the parents, don't you think?) have been considerably mellowed by age and adversity (present company included.) Food today : Breakfast and mid-morning - 2 eggs fried in butter, 2 veg sausages, tea (black), coffee (cream) 6 pecans Lunch - 1 chicken wing, turkey-ham and emmenthal cheese roll-ups, salad with olive oil and balsamic vinegar, 1/2 grapefruit Dinner (planned) - my chicken salad and green salad After-dinner drink - whisky-mac
http://deborama.livejournal.com/5185.html

I have just developed a weird backache.  I am pissed off at my husband.  I am pissed off at the world, come to think of it.  

Food today:

I can't believe it!  I was hit by a car this evening just as I left work.  The lady who hit me was very shaken herself (as who wouldn't be) and we swapped details and 2 young women who witnessed it gave me theirs too.  But I did not want to report it (although I may later, just in the interest of publlic safety statistics) and I did not want to go to A&E in Nottinghmam, where it happened (because if I had I am sure I would still be there and be feeling much worse than I am now).  

Here's what happened : the woman who hit me said she would drive me anywhere (no trivial offer, if you could have seen the state of the traffic) and I said the train station.  Fortunately I was able to get 1) ice for my knee from the coffee kiosk, 2) a direct train home, more or less on time, and 3) a seat on the very crowded train and even near the door which made it much less painful getting off.  I was able to drive the short distance home, and by then I had no doubt that I was in shock (I still am, but getting better).  I had sweet decaf tea and a little brandy and a hot bath and about an hour later, a light supper.  Now I am almost OK - a little drunk, tummy upset, vague beat-up achey feeling, and a very bruised right knee, which took the brunt of it.   I sort of bounced off the front of the car (fortunately she was pulling cautiously into the road and just looking the other way, so the speed was quite low) and flew in a low gentle arc to the ground, landing on one knee and two hands.

I suppose I will go and get checked out tomorrow; I ought to have my knee x-rayed and at my age and with my family history, I worry about blood clots a bit.  But other than that, I am surprisingly OK.  <self-pity>Still, I could use a hug.</self-pity>

OK, I had what I said for tea last night, so that's good.  But then I had a bit more - a small omelette (2 eggs, 1/2 oz. cheese)

BTW, eggs I fix at home will always be free-range, as that's all we buy.  We buy them from the greengrocer.  Cheese will almost always be vegetarian mature cheddar, unless otherwise stated.  Personally, I would buy organic cheese and just eat less of it, but DH won't agree to that.  

We have a vegetable garden and so depending on the season, the following things will be home-grown and almost organic (no pesticides, organic fertilizers wherever possible; we compost vigorously): rocket (arugula); mixed lettuce, chard, beetroot (not eating currently due to Atkins (sigh)), radish, fennel (we grew these but had bad yields), chillis, tomatoes, almost all herbs, esp. parsley and coriander (cilantro), courgettes (zucchini) and other squashes), string beans (again - very low yield this year), sorrell (only from garden), raddichio.  Oddly enough the only things we are currently eating from the garden are chillis (now kind of dried) and tomatoes (hung branches of green ones in the utility room at first frost - this works very well and they are sweet and tasty when they ripen!) and rocket, which just goes on and on and is completely frost-resistant.

This morning, I discovered that DH had just had the last of my decaf Italian coffee.  This after months of moaning that he would never follow my lead and convert to decaf, Atkins or not, because he didn't see the point of decaf.  When he converted, it was sudden and total (he's like that) and he left behind a 1/2 lb. bag of strength 5 coffee.  I made a pot of that, poured half a cup, added lots of cream and topped up the cup with boiling water.  But I'll still be up all night, just watch . . . 
So far I have had that and two fried eggs and two veggie sausages.  This was a new kind of sausage for me (Cauldron cumberland).  Liked the texture; the taste is too salt-and-pepper for me though.  (I shudder to see the TV chefs pour salt and pepper into otherwise appealing recipes.  They are such brutal tastes!  I am very sparing with salt and never use black pepper, preferring white pepper and/or cayenne.)

OK, this is a big leap of faith for me.  First, I have tried and failed many times to do a diet journal.  Second, I am not a fan of public confessions, especially for the fat.  But what the hell.

My current weight is about 209 lbs.  I am about 5'7" and I am 51 years old.  When I started dieting, many, many months ago, I weighed about 225 lbs.  (NB: In England where I live , weight is expressed in stones (14lbs.) and lbs. so I started off at 16 st 1 lb and now weigh 14 st 13 lbs by English reckoning.)  My goal weight is quite modest - my initial goal is to get below 200 lbs, (14 st 4 lbs) then to get below 13 st (so will reach that when I weight 181 lbs.)  Then my ultimate goal is 160 lbs or 11 st 6 lbs.  Why so much?  Well I have a picture of myself at 160 lbs. size 16 American, (18 UK) and granted I was only 25, but frankly I looked fabulous.  So screw BMIs and height-weight tables; I know where I want to be.

I am now doing my second attempt to get through a 2-week Atkins induction.  As a former vegetarian, I find this very challenging, and the main problem for me is not boredom, bad breath or constipation (well, that's a problem, but I can take stuff for that) but the fact that eating no fruit and very little veg makes me feel extremely ill.  But I think I'll do better this time, because in the intervening months since I tried it last time I have altered my diet and got used to eating chicken and fish in large quantities, which I was not used to then.  So we'll see.

large green salad, w/olive oil and garlic*

a little steamed cauliflower*
Those last items are starred because I haven't had dinner yet; that is what's planned.

Today - it being Saturday - I went into Birmingham on the train to check out the new supposedly super-deluxe, drop-dead trendy "shopping experience" which is the re-modeled BullRing.  I also wanted to check out the Birmingham City Markets which I have never seen, and the German Christmas market, which I did see, very briefly, about 4 or 5 years ago.  Generally, I am still glad I went and satisfied my curiosity and some moments were enjoyable, but on the whole, I was not impressed.  The German Market is good and recommended; that said, I didn't buy anything.  I could have.  I have a hard time buying anything in England.  This has been going on for a few years.  Except for tights and underwear and the occasional thing I need.  Going shopping is now mostly a spectator sport.  This strange retail monstrosity I went into - I think it was Selfridge's, but who knows? - was a real turn-off.  I suppose it was drop-dead trendy and it really did make me wish I could drop dead, if only to shock the zombies a little.  Oh, the B'ham city markets are not worth the trip, even if its a short one.  I did discover a very genial old Victorian three-storey Waterstone's with a cosy Costa Coffee (say that three times fast), but all I bought was a coffee.  If you visit my "online bookstore" you may find out why I, the world's most addicted bibliophile, almost never buy books in England anymore either.  That's at http://deboramasbooks.blogspot.com/.
